outcomeList.title: Use IBM App Connect Enterprise to fan-out requests over HTTP and aggregate their responses.

sections.section: This tutorial demonstrates a simple Application that receives an XML format message over HTTP, and fans-out two separate asynchronous HTTP request messages (after simple transformations to a CSV format using a Mapping node). Two separate example back-end Applications are provided which receive these requests, do a trivial transformation to upper-case the data, and reply. The fan-in part of the Application aggregates values from the two response messages together.
This tutorial requires an ACE integration node (or standalone server) which is associated with a local queue manager.

In IBM App Connect Enterprise, an application is a container for all the resources that are required to create a solution. This tutorial provides three Applications in total, one to hold the fan-out / fan-in aggregation flow, and two other back-end Applications. A shared library is used to hold the associated XSD and DFDL message model files which describe the required message formats.

sections.section: When you click Import, three Applications and one shared library will be created in your workspace:

details.details: The Application AggregationHTTPAsync provides a single message flow with HTTPAsyncRequest nodes to fan-out two requests. Two HTTPAsyncResponse nodes fan-in reply messages from the back-end message flows. This Application references the shared library named AggregationHTTPAsyncLib which contains XSD and DFDL message model definitions.
The Application AggregationHTTPBackend1 provides a single message flow which receives a CSV message and uses a Mapping node to upper-case the data and return it over HTTP.
The Application AggregationHTTPBackend2 provides a single message flow which receives a CSV message and uses a Mapping node to upper-case the data and return it over HTTP.

sections.section: For simplicity, the three Applications can all be deployed to the same integration server. Once you import the tutorial, the provided applications are ready to be deployed and tested. Before you do this, you need to create the required MQ queues, as described on the Prepare tab.

sections.section: Although this solution uses HTTP to route messages between the applications, the aggregation nodes require MQ queues to operate.

details.details: Create the default App Connect Enterprise queues in IBM MQ by completing the following steps:

Open the IBM App Connect Enterprise Console. If you don't already have one, create and start a queue manager:
crtmqm qmgr
strmqm qmgr

Next create the queues by typing the following command:
server\sample\wmq\iib_createqueues qmgr
where
qmgr is the queue manager name.
Create an integration node which is associated with the above queue manager by completing the following steps:

In the console window, create an integration node by typing the following command:
mqsicreatebroker TESTNODE -q qmgr

Start the integration node by typing the following command:
mqsistart TESTNODE

Create an integration server associated with the integration node by typing the following command:
mqsicreateexecutiongroup TESTNODE -e default

sections.section: <h4>Test the scenario using the Flow Exerciser

details.details: Look inside the AggregationHTTPAsync Application, and open the message flow also named AggregationHTTPAsync

Click the Flow Exerciser icon to start testing the flow. If your Toolkit is connected to multiple servers, you may be asked which one you would like to use. Select an Integration Server under the node which you prepared to work with MQ in the Prepare section.
Click the Send Message icon , choose the provided InputMessage and click Send.
Note that the input XML message has string values in lower case:
<Message>
<Backend1><FieldA>hello</FieldA><FieldB>world</FieldB><FieldC>backend1</FieldC></Backend1>
<Backend2><FieldA>greetings</FieldA><FieldB>globe</FieldB><FieldC>backend2</FieldC></Backend2>
</Message>

The Flow Exerciser should report that an HTTP Reply message has been received. Note that this response message has string values in upper case which has occurred as a result of the aggregation's invocation of the backend services:
<Message>
<Backend1><FieldA>HELLO</FieldA><FieldB>WORLD</FieldB><FieldC>BACKEND1</FieldC></Backend1>
<Backend2><FieldA>GREETINGS</FieldA><FieldB>GLOBE</FieldB><FieldC>BACKEND2</FieldC></Backend2>
</Message>
Close the Flow Exerciser:
You should be able to see the path which the message followed through the flow.
Click on the flow connections to see what the message tree looked like as it traversed through the Integration Service.

sections.section: This tutorial has shown the Aggregation nodes orchestrating an asynchronous fan-out and an associated fan-in of messages using the HTTP transport to back-end services.
